did.unittitle: Collection of research materials related to Linguistic-Psychological studies of Genie (pseudonym)
did.abstract: "Genie" (b. 1957) is the pseudonym of a young girl raised in an abusive and isolated environment until the age of 13. The collection consists of material that chronicles her discovery and the study and rehabilitation efforts of researchers. Items include reports and essays; correspondence; notes; medical records; diagnostic material; legal paperwork such as depositions, summonses, and settlement agreements; pedagogical material; administrative paperwork; Genie's artwork; articles and clippings; photographs and slides; audio-visual videotapes, cassettes, and film; assorted printed material; and ephemera.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is closed to access, except for those individual files that are explicitly noted as open for research in the Container List. Please contact Special Collections reference (AskLSC@library.ucla.edu) for more information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: The materials in the collection raise privacy and confidentiality concerns that prevent the University from granting access to the majority of materials. The files that are open to research are explicitly noted in the finding aid. All other files unless noted are closed to research. The University does not hold any copyrights in these materials and cannot grant permission to copy or publish. Any person seeking to publish the materials would have to resolve potential issues concerning copyright, statutory protection of medical records (HIPAA), and common law and California constitutional privacy. The University cannot address or resolve these issues. While the University is able to provide access to some of the materials for personal research purposes, it cannot provide access beyond this narrow restriction nor grant permission to copy or publish."

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Collection of Research Materials related to Linguistic-Psychological Studies of Genie (pseudonym) (Collection 800). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Sheehan with assistance from Laurel McPhee, 2006.

The materials in this collection had been in the possession of Dr. David Rigler, a lead investigator in the Genie studies, since 1975. He stored the materials in his office and/or residence following the conclusion of the research in the mid to late Seventies. The collection was boxed and shipped to Dr. Susan Curtiss, UCLA Department of Linguistics, in 2005. Manuscripts Division staff completed a box-level inventory at that time. The papers were dehumidified with silica gel beads, and treated for potential insect infestation with sticky traps and boric acid bait. In early 2006, Timothy Holland created a preliminary inventory of the audio visual materials, and Elizabeth Sheehan began processing the papers under the supervision of Laurel McPhee. Materials were placed into folders, described, and arranged into series and subseries levels to enhance access to the collection and to create a finding aid.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: "Genie" is the pseudonym of a 13 year old girl who, on November 4, 1970, was admitted to Childrens Hospital Los Angeles as a victim of extreme isolation and deprivation by her immediate family. She was discovered after a Department of Social Services case worker took note of Genie when her mother, who was losing her eyesight, visited Social Services seeking assistance for the blind. Subsequent medical and psychological tests at Childrens Hospital noted that Genie had language and motor skills far below her age level.

In 1971, Childrens Hospital staff members intimately involved in Genie's case applied to the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) for grant funding to study Genie's case history and developmental progress during rehabilitation efforts. A grant was approved and from 1971 to 1975 Childrens Hospital of Los Angeles (CHLA) administered the study entitled "Developmental Consequence of Extreme Social Isolation," under the direction of Dr. David Rigler. During the course of the study, members of the research team included other CHLA staff, UCLA Department of Linguistics researchers (including Dr. Susan Curtiss and Dr. Victoria Fromkin), and a variety of external consultants.

In August 1971, it was determined that for Genie's benefit she should be removed from the hospital environment and be placed in a foster home. Because of her unique and severe case, placement was difficult and it was eventually determined that she would reside with David and Marilyn Rigler. The Riglers, in addition to being research team members, were Genie's foster parents from 1971 to 1975. This unusual situation would be a factor in a lawsuit later filed by Genie's mother.

In 1975, NIMH declined to renew the grant and the study came to a close. Genie's placement with the Riglers also came to an end. Now 18 years old and legally an adult, she was released to the care of her mother, who was unable to cope with Genie's special needs. Genie was then placed in a foster home, which proved to be especially detrimental to her progress and psychological well-being. As a result, she was readmitted to Childrens Hospital in 1977 for two weeks. Upon her release, Genie was placed in another foster home.

In 1979, Genie's mother filed a lawsuit (C 276 459) against Childrens Hospital Los Angeles and David Rigler, Howard Hansen, James Kent, Vrinda Knapp, and Susan Curtiss, individually. In the suit, she alleged that CHLA and the various defendants violated the physician-patient, psycho-therapist relationship of Genie and herself when confidential information was revealed publicly. The suit was settled in 1984 and the acrimony of the lawsuit temporarily severed the relationship between the researchers and Genie's mother, resulting in several years of non-communication with her and Genie. However, in 1992 Dr. David Rigler and Genie's mother reestablished communication, and the Riglers, subsequently, visited with Genie.

Although not indicated in the collection files, according to Russ Rymer, author of the book Genie: A Scientific Tragedy, by the early 1990s Genie was living in an adult home for the intellectually disabled, where it is believed she remains in 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection documents the psycholinguistic study of Genie (pseudonym), a young girl discovered at the age of 13 to have been kept for many years in conditions of extreme isolation and deprivation by her family. The materials in this collection primarily document a National Institute of Mental Health study grant (MH 21191) entitled "Developmental Consequence of Extreme Social Isolation," which was administered by Childrens Hospital of Los Angeles under the primary direction of Dr. David Rigler. In addition to the formal study material, the collection also documents the foster care of Genie by David and Marilyn Rigler from 1971 to 1975, and a California lawsuit (case number C 276459) brought by Genie's mother against Childrens Hospital and individuals affiliated with the study. The collection consists of a variety of material including reports and papers authored by those associated with the study, study notes, correspondence, diagnostic and pedagogical material, medical records, Genie's art work, funding paperwork, guardianship material, legal material, photographs, and an abundance of audio-visual material.

arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Audio visual materials, 1970-1993 (44 boxes, 2 shoeboxes, and 2 oversize boxes), subseries A-E as follows:

8C. Family history
8D. Genie's artwork

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series consists of audio and visual materials created during the linguistic-psychological studies of Genie. The material shows a variety of researchers, teachers, therapists and scholars interacting with Genie. The footage also documents Genie's behavior during her rehabilitation, life with the Riglers, testing phases, and everyday activities.

Arranged in subseries A-E as follows:
1A. 1/2" video tapes
1B. VHS cassettes
1C. Mini DVCs and Hi8 P6-120HMP video
D. Super 8 mm film
1E. Audio materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of video tapes taken of Genie between 1970 and 1977. The videos were numbered and listed in a basic subject index by researchers; this index is augmented by detailed descriptions of the following tapes: 2-3, 87-88, 90, 96, 101, 110, 111, 114, 115, 116. There are also brief descriptions for most of the tapes numbered 127-193. The original index and tape descriptions have been filed in box 1 at the beginning of the subseries. The main video format used was Sony Helical Scan (V-30D and V-30H) 1/2 inch video tape reels; unless otherwise noted, that is the format found throughout the subseries. For reformatted VHS cassette recordings of this material, see Subseries IB. VHS cassettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Assorted typewritten materials documenting the original numbering scheme, description, and VHS cassette restoration for the 1/2" video tape reels. Descriptions for these materials were compiled for the finding aid by checking the original index against the descriptions adhering to, or written directly on, the tape containers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of VHS video cassettes. Most of the cassettes are numbered and correspond to the 1/2" tape reel numbers found in Subseries 1A. There are also eight VHS cassettes of Genie footage labeled WGBH. These contain some reformatted material off the 1/2" video tape reels, and possibly some original or composite footage gathered for the television show NOVA. All label and number information was transcribed directly off the cassette boxes to create a listing for the finding aid.

did.unittitle: 1C. Mini DVCs and Hi8 P6-120HMP video

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 122 miniature digital video cassettes and two Hi8 videos. The DVCs were created by the Tokyo Broadcasting System in 2003 as a stipulation of their use of 1/2" tape reels, Super 8 mm films, and still photographs of Genie for a documentary television show entitled "3.8 Billion Years of Life: What is Man? Park IV." Most of the DVC tapes are numbered and correspond to the 1/2" tape reel numbers found in Subseries 1A. The 1/2" video tape reel numbers duplicated here include: 2-9, 11-13, 16-25, 27, 30, 41-44, 49-52, 54, 56, 59, 63, 65-69, 71, 73-86, 89-90, 92, 94, 98-101, 105-108, 112-113, 115-121, 127-190, 134-138, 140- 144, 149-150, 159, 164, 167, 172, 183-184, 214, 223, 228-229, 232-233, 237, 239-241, 402, 414, 417, 418-419, 421-423, 425-427, 432 and 436. Ten additional mini DVCs, stored in box 46, contain copies of unidentified 8mm film reels, an undated dental examination, and copies of the Hi8 video material. The two Hi8 video cassettes, also located in box 46, contain footage of Genie from December 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of film footage of Genie, primarily taken by David or Marilyn Rigler. Footage includes outings and everyday activities at school and around the home. The reels were originally labeled by general subject content in David Rigler's handwriting; he also gave each reel a number, beginning with reel no. 12. His notations on the outside of the boxes were used to create the titles seen here in the finding aid. The Rigler numbers were also noted and retained during processing. All film is Super 8 mm Kodak Ektachrome stock, unless otherwise noted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of audio recordings and audio cassette tapes relating to Genie. The audio reels include: one 3 1/2" reel of an interview with Stephanie Heinzmann, DPSS employee, dated 1970 December 8; two 3 1/2" reels of meetings attended by the Kirks, Jean Butler, David Rigler, H. Hansen, and James Kent dated 1972 February 2; six 7" reels dated 1972 November 7-12; one 3 1/2" reel labeled "Conference with Block, Hansen, Kent, Rigler, 1975 February 24"; and four unidentified reels. Audio cassette tapes include: one tape labeled "Conference with Genie's teacher, 1973 March 28"; one tape labeled "Rymer, NPR Fresh Air, 1993 April 9."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of various conference papers, essays, and reports written by research team members and study consultants regarding their work with Genie or with related and applicable research topics. Photocopies of published journal articles generally related to child development, child psychology, and abuse were removed from the collection during processing. A bibliography of these materials is stored in the collection file and is available upon request.

3A. Childrens Hospital of Los Angeles
3B. Grant Foundation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series consists of administrative paperwork related to personnel issues for research team members, correspondence and memorandums, interview notes and transcriptions, and examples of Genie's artwork. Series also contains items related to specific research issues, including material from consultants, essays and articles, related case study examples, pedagogical material, and assorted printed material. Some of these materials, due to privacy concerns, may be inaccessible to researchers. Please consult the Manuscripts Librarian in advance so that access arrangements can be made as appropriate.

Arranged in subseries A-H as follows:
8A. Administrative
8B. Correspondence
8C. Family history
8D. Genie's artwork
8E. Language, sleep and social behavior
8F. Miscellaneous
8G. Notes
8H. Testing.
